doc.title: Silvio Berlusconi: the rise and fall
doc.author: Tom Kington
doc.description: Timeline: the political ups and downs of the media magnate's career as Italy's leader
doc.tags: Italy,Europe,World news,Silvio Berlusconi,Euro,European Union,Economics,Elections past,Politics past,Politics

main.p: After the Clean Hands anti-corruption investigation decimates Italy's political parties, and only three months after he forms his Forza Italia party, media magnate Berlusconi wins parliamentary election.

As investigators launch a bribery probe involving Berlusconi's Fininvest holding, his government coalition partner Umberto Bossi, head of the Northern League, pulls out of the government, forcing Berlusconi to resign.

Berlusconi wins national elections after signing a "contract" with Italy on TV promising to lower taxes, create jobs and build infrastructure. He also promises to resolve the conflicts of interest which his business interests would pose.
Loses national election to Romano Prodi after performing badly in a TV debate where he grows visibly irritated. Refuses to concede defeat at polls, alleging irregularities.
Heart surgery to install a pacemaker at a clinic in the US, three weeks after collapsing while delivering a speech. Continues to boast he has the stamina of a younger man and will live to be 120.
After Prodi's coalition of Catholics-to-former-Communists collapses after 18 months, Berlusconi wins a convincing victory over former Rome mayor and lefftist Walter Veltroni, and starts third term.
Veronica Lario, Berlusconi's second wife, announces she wants divorce, after denouncing her husband for wanting to send young showgirls and Big Brother contestants to Brussels as MEPs.
Prostitute Patrizia D'Addario claims she had spent the night at Berlusconi's Rome residence after joining 20 women for a party with champagne and jokes by Berlusconi.
Indicted by a Milan court on charges he paid an underage girl, Ruby Heartstealer, for sex, and used his position to try to cover up the subsequent disclosure.

After the erosion of his parliamentary majority, Berlusconi informs Italy's president, Giorgio Napolitano, a veteran former Communist, that he will resign as prime minister â€“ but says equivocally that it will be sometime in November, after he has passed economic reforms that have been demanded by the EU.
